description: THE OWNER OF MARCY'S department store is furious. "Maybe they let chickens play Santa in Arkansas," he shouts, "but that's not how we do things in New York City."

title: Establishing Folk Art's Pedigree
description: THOUGH "A World of Their Own" may seem like a departure for the Newark Museum, it is actually a kind of reprise, for the institution was the first of its kind to show folk art, in 1930. Holger Cahill, who had joined the museum a decade earlier, organized the display, another that followed a year later and a third that took place at the Museum of Modern Art, where he became acting director, in 1932.

title: A Generation's Heritage: After the Boom, a Boomlet
description: Once again, it's the invasion of the stroller people.

title: F.D.A. Becomes Target Of Empowered Groups
description: Among the Republicans in Congress and their allies in conservative advocacy groups, the Food and Drug Administration has become the first and biggest target in the push for deregulation.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Frank Catania;
A Watchdog for the Casino Industry
description: WITH the easing of state regulations that control Atlantic City's casinos and renewed interest in licensing applications there, Frank Catania foresees challenges very different from those he faced as an Assemblyman. Mr. Catania resigned his legislative seat last September to become acting director of the division of gaming enforcement of the Department of Law and Public Safety.

title: Freestyler Takes Rhymes From Streets to a Recording
description: Super Natural is sitting on an ottoman in his apartment, shoeless and rhyming to himself. He's been rhyming for hours, and the presence of guests doesn't break his mood. It inspires him.

title: The Windfall in Volleyball
description: A LITTLE more than two years ago, when Billy Bloom was writing television commercials and Richard Gilbert was editing concert booklets, the two would eagerly wait for work to be over so they could lace up their sneakers, get to the gym and head for the net.

title: New Musical Headed For American Stage
description: UPON the dawning of a musical comedy at American Stage, commercial producers listen for the serious sound of money. Out of six new song-filled shows that have had premieres in the company's nine seasons, four (most famously, "Forever Plaid") with significant signs of life after Teaneck have been sighted.

title: Doorman's Tale: Scenes From a Former Life
description: THREE or four years ago, as Al Weaver tells it, an old buddy passed him at work on East 22d Street.

title: War and Angst
description: ALL OUR YESTERDAYSBy Robert B. Parker.401 pp. New York:Delacorte Press.

title: An Evangelist on Playing Bridge Seeks Out the Younger Set
description: ON a recent rainy Monday night Michael Kufs was working up a sweat as he preached to a crowd at Temple Judea in Manhasset.

title:
The View From: Sandy Hook;
Keeping It Calm in the Vineyards Where the Eagles Fly
description: DAWN had barely come to the Housatonic, but Evan Maranville was poised, camera in hand, to capture the morning wing stretches and dives for fish by the almost 20 bald eagles that perch and feed at McLaughlin Vineyards in Sandy Hook.

title: February 5-11; The House's Gift to the President
description: Since the beginning of the Republic, the only way the President has been able to block legislation passed by Congress has been to veto the measure in its entirety. This has been the essence of Congress's power over the purse. It has also been the foundation of the pork barrel.

title: Sports of The Times; Yes, Santa, There Is A Virginia
description: JUST asking. Is baseball's proposed expansion franchise in northern Virginia connected to the club owners' lobby in Washington?

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CAMPFIRE OUTING

title:
MUSIC;
A Nod to Some 'Forgotten' Romantics
description: APTLY titled "Buried Treasures: The Romantics," a concert by the Wayne Chamber Orchestra will present rarely heard works by Prokofiev, Dvorak and Joan Tower and the first performance since 1941 of Leo Sowerby's Piano Concerto No. 2 in E.

title: Broad Terror Campaign Is Foiled By Fire in Kitchen, Officials Say
description: The neighbors had wondered what was going on behind the locked door of Apartment 603, but it wasn't until there was a small fire in the apartment last month that they learned the truth about their mysterious, silent neighbor.

title: Problems for Bodine
description: Nascar barred BRETT BODINE from qualifying yesterday for the Daytona 500 and levied a record $45,000 fine against the owner of his car, JUNIOR JOHNSON, after inspectors discovered an illegal engine piece that would have made the car faster.

title: Reducing Taxes on Property
description: YOU can't fight city hall?

title: Physicians Are Joining Group Care
description: LONG Island physicians, who have traditionally practiced alone or in small groups, are trying to adapt in many ways as corporations increasingly move into managing medical care.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DAN STUART'S FISTIC CARNIVAL By Leo N. Miletich.Texas A & M University,cloth, $29.50; paper, $14.95.

title: Bookshelf
description: FREDERICK DOUGLASS: In His Own Words. Edited by Milton Meltzer. Illustrated by Stephen Alcorn. Harcourt Brace. $22. (Ages 12 and up) This eloquent selection of annotated writings not from his autobiographies can introduce Douglass, or supplement other readings. Complete with helpful annotations, biographical sketches, sources and index. Dramatic linocut illustrations.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FULTON FERRY Royal Musical Treatment In a Unique River Setting

title: Alan G. Mnuchin, Kimberly E. Kassel
description: Kimberly Ellen Kassel, the daughter of Mrs. Ted Kohl of New York and stepdaughter of Mr. Kohl, was married in New York yesterday to Alan Geoffrey Mnuchin, a son of Elaine T. Cooper and Robert Mnuchin, both of New York. Rabbi Richard Chapin officiated at the Pierre.

title: College Protest Brings Course Changes
description: AFTER students at Westchester Community College mounted a campaign for a black studies department last year, Dr. Joseph N. Hankin, president of the college, formed a task force to study the issue.

title: THE POSTURE PHOTO SCANDAL
description: The college posture photo is a subject that has haunted me since I was one of a freshman class of shivering, uncomfortable young women herded into a gym where nude photographs were taken at Radcliffe in the 1950's ("The Great Ivy League Nude Posture Photo Scandal," by Ron Rosenbaum, Jan. 15).

title: Tourism in Japan Mostly Unaffected by Quake
description: THE great earthquake that devastated parts of western Japan on Jan. 17 has created only minor inconveniences for most foreign tourists. At the same time, it has cleared the throngs of tourists who usually pervade the ancient capital of Kyoto, so that the city is now more enchanting than ever.

title: On the Subject Of Highway Tolls
description: In the article "Turnpike Toll: Up, but When?" (Jan. 22), we are told that the question is not whether there will be a turnpike toll increase, "There will be" -- the real issue is when and how much. We are also told that opposition to the toll increase comes from communities that fear greater use of local streets by trucks if there is another substantial increase.

title: Land of 4,000 Unreadable Rules
description: THE DEATH OF COMMON SENSEHow Law Is Suffocating America.By Philip K. Howard.202 pp. New York: Random House. $18.

title: Conservative Champion Arrives From Rust Belt
description: Pudgy, balding and a plodding orator, Gov. John M. Engler has become an unlikely face of revolution.

title: Honoring the Past in the Borough of Homes
description: On the 30th anniversary of New York's landmarks preservation law, the city's largest and second most populous borough still has the fewest landmarks. For years, preservationists complained that politics were felling Queens's architectural and historical prizes.

title: Correction
description: A report in the "Sunday" pages on Jan. 29 about the Center for the Arts in California described its location imprecisely. Yerba Buena Gardens is a cultural center in downtown San Francisco, not a separate town.

title: Abuse Panel Sees Encouraging Sign in Lower Child Death Figure
description: Thirty-seven children whose families had troubled histories that were known to New York City child protection officials died in 1993, the lowest number of such child deaths since 1985, according to a city report issued last week.

title:
BACKTALK -- Major Beleaguered Baseball: The Principals in Their Words;
All Compromise Came From The Players
description: The baseball negotiations broke down late last Tuesday in Washington. It was the fourth time in six months that the owners walked away from the bargaining table.

title: In Canada, Doubts Fade Quickly About Trade Accord
description: WHILE the United States and Mexico are still recovering from battles fought during the first year of the North American Free Trade Agreement, Canada, which was dragged kicking and screaming into the arrangements, has emerged as the real winner.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Viewpoints section on Jan. 29, about the corporate presence in American schools, incorrectly attributed a statement to Keep America Beautiful, a nonprofit education organization that provides materials for use in classrooms. The group never published the statement, "incinerating plastics is a form of recycling."

title: Washington Talk; Pentagon Bargain Prices* (*An Additional Cost for Wars)
description: For the low, low price of $264 billion, the Pentagon's budget this year trains and equips 1.6 million troops, buys new warships and fighter jets and builds new barracks. Wars? Sorry, those are extra.

title:
FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Pinching Centimes On St. Barts
description: WHEN I told people I was going to St. Barthelemy I tended to get two sorts of reaction: knowing smiles from those who had been to that little island in the French Antilles and appreciated its singular charms or outraged stories about its horrendously steep prices. Indeed, a woman I met on the plane going down reported that she'd fallen in love with a silk jacket she found in a shop on St. Barts, but got a case of sticker-shock when she checked the price tag -- a cool $3,000.

title: Islanders Score Late and Not Much, but Win Anyway
description: It has almost become a given this season that the Islanders will fall behind early any time they play.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Views Shift On Insanity In Killings On L.I.R.R.
description: Carolyn McCarthy and many of the other family members of the victims of the Long Island Rail Road shootings have changed their minds about Colin Ferguson. They no longer think he's crazy.

title: Replenish the Peace Process
description: President Clinton has gathered the top diplomats of Israel, Egypt and Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization along with Secretary of State Warren Christopher today in Washington to revitalize the drive for Middle East peace, particularly the talks between Israel and the P.L.O. Suicide bombings by radical Palestinians, border closures, growing talk of "separation" by Israelis and Yasir Arafat's complaints about election delays have created a bleak mood. It need not be so.

title: Ranger Victory Secures A Share of First Place
description: On a night the Rangers could have easily rationalized their way to another defeat, playing their third game in four days and a road game at that, they drew a little on last season's Stanley Cup magic.

title:
CLASSICAL MUSIC;
A Bad Girl Calms Down, a Bit
description: Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg has never liked to play safe. She once went deep-sea fishing, caught a 275-pound shark and ended up with a sore shoulder. She used to smoke three packs of cigarettes a day, extinguishing them only to go on stage. And even after a decadelong career as a professional violinist, she says, she has never owned a pair of gloves.

title: New Generation Is Going Platinum
description: FIVE years ago, when Scott Kay, a jewelry designer, announced a new collection of platinum engagement rings, the idea went over like a black wedding gown.

title: Retooling Poly Prep
description: THE chapel at Poly Prep comes straight out of central casting (boys' school, old-line; jump-cut to summers in Quogue). There's the dark woodwork, the stiff-backed pews, the framed black-and-white photographs of alumni killed on the battlefields of World War II. One expects a plump and pink-faced chaplain, intoning something from the Book of Common Prayer.

title: High Hopes, Mixed Fortunes And the New Promised Land
description: FROM THE DEPRESSION TO the years of the civil rights movement, a desperate river of people barely noted by the mainstream transformed the American North. They were sharecroppers and domestics and other put-upon products of Southern segregation who rebelled in their own iron way, heading north on trains and buses in what came to be known as the Great Migration.

title: Connecticut Premiere For Piano Concerto
description: WHO'S supposed to play this?" asked the pianist Michael Boriskin, in mock hysteria. The question was posed over the phone to George Perle, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer.

title: Journal; White History Month
description: The last thing I ever expected was to get sucked into Black History Month. In my high school, we simply didn't have black history. Some days we didn't even have white history.

title: LEONARDO DiCAPRIO
description: THE BOY WITH THE MOST beautiful name in Hollywood was once told by an agent to change it to Lenny Williams. More recently, producers have advised him to star in movies about demonic teen-agers who strangle their girlfriends, or in tacky, fast-money Westerns like "The Quick and the Dead," which opened Friday. And it has not been uncommon for strangers to offer him cocaine and heroin at industry parties. In his short career -- he just turned 20 -- Leonardo DiCaprio has seen all the twisted ways people respond to a prodigy's gift: change it, own it. Shooting "The Basketball Diaries," due out in April, he was trailed by flocks of pubescent girls, who recognized him from the sitcom "Growing Pains." A mother who spied him blowing bubbles between takes on location in New Jersey ordered her barely ambulatory toddler to go up and hug the famous young man.

title: Diagnosis: Treatment Pending
description: NEARLY every man over age 50 should have an annual blood test to detect prostate cancer, said Dr. Joseph E. Oesterling, chairman of the urology department at the University of Michigan. The test has been shown to be reliable in detecting aggressive tumors years before symptoms appear. And prostate cancer is a major killer of men, second only to lung cancer. So why should anyone turn down a chance for early detection and treatment?

title: Is It Magic Or Mania for Tech Stocks?
description: JUST when you thought the initial public offering market was dead, up leaps evidence of speculative fervor that just won't quit. These days, that emotion is in technology. Just using words like semiconductors, software and the information highway can get investors salivating.

title: It Seems That Only the Rangers Bring Out Best in Devils
description: Showing little of the emotion and firepower that had propelled them to victory over the archrival Rangers two nights earlier, the Devils were a mistake-prone imitation of themselves in tonight's 3-1 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers.

title:
TECHNOLOGY VIEW;
Mini-Systems Off the Top Shelf (and Others)
description: IN THE MID-1970'S, "MINI" AUDIO components hit the United States market for the first time. When American consumers eyed those tiny boxes, they stroked their chins and offered a collective response along the lines of, "Hmmm, they certainly are, uh, small."

title: Cyberights
description: ABOUT 20 YEARS AGO, WHILE answering an intrusive telephone poll, I stumbled on a bit of legal philosophy that could serve the planet for at least a century. I am assuming (a) that the 21st will be the Information Century, (b) that there will be no World War III to distract humanity from its lust for trade and profit and (c) that post-Marxist China will by then have stopped selling goods based on copyright theft.

title:
OUT OF ORDER;
Feb. 14? Just Another Pressure Point
description: THE florist's shop is usually a quiet and fragrant place. This week it is a battle zone. Even the cuddly bears look worried. How will everything be finished before the 14th? The store is jammed with irritable men who are cursing the price of red roses and express delivery. Give time to love, says the proverb. But those guys cannot afford to. Their love, or loves, have to be packed up and delivered right away, so that they can get back to all the other things they left to the last minute.

title: Greedy Owners
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: The Unfinished Man
description: MARRYING & BURYINGRites of Passage in a Man's Life.By Ronald L. Grimes.Illustrated. 262 pp.Boulder, Colo.: Westview Press.Cloth, $59.50. Paper, $18.95.

title: Shades of Difference
description: THE WEDDING By Dorothy West. 240 pp. New York: Doubleday. $20.

title: Mets' Campers Will Start At the Minor League Park
description: The Mets' major league clubhouse will be empty when spring training opens Thursday. The corner locker that has belonged to Dwight Gooden for years will have no new inhabitant. The whirlpool will be silent, the training room unused.

title: Eldredge Proves Demise Is Greatly Exaggerated
description: He had gone four years since his last national figure-skating title, his ascendancy interrupted by injury, sagging confidence and illness, and there were many wondering when and if Todd Eldredge would ever get back to the top after such a prolonged fall.

title: February 5-11: Fighting Terrorism; World Trade Center Suspect, One of F.B.I.'s Most-Wanted, Is Captured in Pakistan
description: Ramzi Ahmed Yousef's angular face was familiar from his photograph on the F.B.I.'s Most Wanted List, but it was the hands, deeply scarred from explosive burns, that Government agents said confirmed their suspicion that they had caught up with the suspected mastermind of the World Trade Center bombing. Mr. Yousef was picked up at an Islamabad rooming house by Pakistani authorities on Tuesday morning and turned over to a 20-member team of F.B.I. agents who flew him back to New York City.

title: Sink the Kon-Tiki!
description: VOYAGE OF REDISCOVERYA Cultural Odyssey Through Polynesia.By Ben Finney with Marlene Among,Chad Baybayan, Tai Crouch, Paul Frost,Bernard Kilonsky, Richard Rhodes,Thomas Schroeder, Dixon Stroup, NainoaThompson, Robert Worthington and Elisa Yadao.Illustrated by Richard Rhodes.401 pp. Berkeley:University of California Press. $30.

title: Here Come the Mighty Lady Huskies
description: THEY walk across campus. Rebecca Lobo, at 6 foot 4, is bookended by her 5-foot-5 and 5-foot-6 teammates, Jennifer Rizzotti and Pam Webber. It's the start of the new semester and Jen has five minutes to get to philosophy class.

title: Last Governor Without Veto Could Get It
description: Finally shedding its fear of England's colonial governors, the North Carolina Legislature has approved a constitutional amendment that would give the Governor the veto, a power denied the state's chief executive since the Revolution.

title: At Work; Stalking the Useful Career Guide
description: MAYBE it wasn't exactly the harmonic convergence, but something collided last week when the mail brought both a harbinger of the future, "The On-Line Job Search Companion," and a blast from the past, the latest edition of "What Color Is Your Parachute?" The two couldn't be more of a study in contrasts: the business-like, almost grim "Companion" versus the amused and amusing "Parachute," the former aimed at anxious slackers, the latter traditionally viewed as the book Allen Ginsberg would have used if he had ever wanted to get a day job. Which is better? Surprise! It depends.

title:
STYLE;
Dial-a-Bar
description: One day last summer, my friend Dee and I agreed to meet at the Phone Bar the following evening. Her novel had just gotten a good review and she wanted to celebrate. So at 5:30 the next day, my kids were in the dining room surrounded by toys and markers and paper; a bottle of Scotch and a glass of ice were on my desk across the hall, the telephone rang and there I was -- in the Phone Bar. At the other end, Dee was drinking a vodka martini on the rocks.

title: A PC Elitist Turns Crowd Pleaser
description: FOR the first decade of the personal computer revolution, the Hewlett-Packard Company had the dubious distinction of being the most prestigious manufacturer consigned to that great wedge of market share charts dubbed "other."

title: Vietnamese Open Office To Improve U.S. Ties
description: When Hanoi opened its first diplomatic office here last week, the chief of liaison was met with angry shouts from protesters. In the days that followed, however, the downtown suite of offices has filled up with flowers from American companies eager to do business with the former foe.

title: For Actors, a Casting Call And a Cautionary Note
description: THEY had seen the posters for an open casting call for Francis Ford Coppola's "On the Road," and they had come, draining every Barnes & Noble in the city of the so-titled Jack Kerouac novel along the way.

title: Paying The Price For Blowing The Whistle
description: FOR three years, Arnold Gundersen was awakened by harassing phone calls in the middle of the night. He became so concerned about his family's safety that he bought a large dog for protection. The problem? He was a whistle-blower, one of those who take on the dismally unpopular role of exposing what they find to be unsafe or unlawful practices in the workplace, especially the nuclear workplace.

title: Only Champions Allowed in Top Show
description: In the political arena, in 1877, Rutherford B. Hayes was serving his first year as President of the United States. In the racing world, the Kentucky Derby had its third running, with Baden Baden winning a $3,300 purse. In the dog show ring, the Westminster Kennel Club held its very first event.

title: From Wicked Witch to 'Magic Flute,' a Day of Operatic Matinees
description: ALL manner of musical events brighten the Sunday music calendar today, with no less than three operatic matinees. First up, at 1:30, the Wicked Witch gets hers in Crystal Opera's "Hansel and Gretel" at Stamford's Ethel Kweskin-Sterling Barn Theater, with repeat performances of the Humperdinck favorite at 8 P.M. Saturday and 2 P.M. next Sunday afternoon. Those performances will be in Norwalk at the Roosevelt Senior Center. The numbers for more details are 849-1730 and 847-4850.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Diary column last Sunday about the new Denver airport misstated the status of the automated baggage system. When the airport opens on Feb. 28, the system will be used for all outbound United Airlines flights, roughly 60 percent of all outbound flights. The other outbound flights, and all the inbound flights, will use a traditional system.

title: In Scratching the Entrepreneurial Itch, the Frames Had It
description: SET roots down in the suburbs, cherish the family and have a career simultaneously -- Gianna (Gigi) Dekko Goldman, founder of Gianna International, a specialty frame maker in Rowayton wanted it all.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract. MANHATTAN GRAMERCY PARK AREA $520,000 112 East 19th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,850-sq.-ft. co-op in a loft building; dining area, high-ceilings, h/w floors, 3 exposures; maintenance $1,555, 44% tax-deductible, listed at $595,000, 21 weeks on market (Brokers: D.J. Knight; Halstead Property Co.)

title: February 5-11: Protest at Rutgers; Embattled President Backed by University's Board
description: "The crisis," is now the common campus shorthand at Rutgers University for the 11 days of turmoil and student demonstrations aimed at toppling the president, Francis L. Lawrence, for his remarks about the "genetic hereditary background" of students who do not perform well on college admissions tests.

title: Who Are Those Guys? Veil of Secrecy to Be Lifted Soon
description: A truck driver double-parked outside Shea Stadium the other day, went inside for about an hour, threw some pitches for Mets officials and now won't be driving a truck much longer. But who was that masked man?

title: A City Built on $4.25 an Hour
description: IN Washington people talk a lot about the minimum wage these days, but few try to live with it. This is a place where people actually do.

title: Amanda Gimble, Myron Glucksman
description: Amanda Lynne Gimble, a director of corporate strategy and planning at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, is to marry Myron Samuel Glucksman, a vice president at Citicorp Securities in New York, today at the St. Regis. Rabbi Daniel Mehlman is to officiate in New York.

title: Passionate Intensity
description: What we have in poetry, it appears, is poetry in a vacuum, which is even worse than poetry in a Salad Shooter or a hot-air corn popper. There is no consensus about the culture, and therefore no common ground on which poets, critics, scholars, students or even readers (are there any left?) can share assumptions and discuss with some coherence the great questions of life and art.

title: A Homeless Mind
description: THE GATES By Chuck Wachtel. 405 pp. New York: Viking. $23.95.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 12, 1995
